reviewText:
I have over 1000 hours in this game. I love it. Truly.

I cannot recommend it anymore.

The game was updated in January to it's current build, 1.5. They switched to a new server-side hit detection system. Now nothing works. Hits don't work. Blocks don't work. Interrupts don't work.

The game, in it's current state, is unplayable. It is a shadow of its former self.

Save your money.

reviewText: I used to adore this game. Since alpha, I had strived to get better and better. Sure the game was laggy and all, but the game still had a pretty high skill cap, and on a high level the combat was pretty different from something like Warband because of the dodges and specials. It was also much simpler than War of the Roses. I haven't played in a while, but since alpha the game has been intolerably laggy in half the games I have played, but instead of fixing this, the developers added more and more DLC and whatnot. I also believe that the competitive scene and the community in general is more or less dead by now, and there won't be any more updates to this completely unpolished game. The game had potential in the alpha, and I had a lot of fun with it, but now it's definitely not worth the price.

reviewText:
EDIT:
Quite possibly the buggiest, laggiest and sloppiest production of all time. You have to say it exemplifies Fatshark's ineptitude at making a game that is even slightly polished. Frankly, it is an utter embarrassment in that regard.

ORIGINAL:
Having played the first installment of the 'War of' games for over 1500 hours one might be inclined to call me a fan of the style of game Fatshark had created and I was hugely enthusiatic about the next chapter in what could be a blossoming franchise.

However,  the game has failed miserably in delivering an improved performance and gaming experience on the previous game. This is a watered down version of War of the Roses, but by no means does that make it easy. Hitboxes are non-existent as the game is all about movement of you body postion rather than skill/precision of aiming your weapon and feinting attacks. Consequently if you get average FPS (like me) then you need to steer well clear of this title as smoothness is imperative.

FIghting mechanics seemed to have had a huge overhaul in WotV, which isn't necessarily a good thing. There are 3 ways to attack (when in melee combat) instead of the 4 in WotR and there are perks that can give you 'autoblock' for one specific direction, taking the total number of ways to concentrate on to 2. You also have the ability to carry out special attacks, which if connect give insta-kills (or so I believe). Thanks to the above the game provides no real satisfaction when killing an opponent (during melee), as you don't feel like it materialized through your in-game education or skill progression, but rather came about thanks to the hack and slash elements of the game. Don't get me wrong, there is skill in EVERY game, but it isn't a skill that inspires you to learn more, want more and basically....play more.

Ranged wise the game has got similarities to WotR and there wasn't a desperate need for change, as the ranged system was smooth and worked well. It was satisfying and still is, with the addition of throwing weapons like axes etc it has added another string to it's bow, so to speak, so all in all ranged is pretty good.

In addition to the new implementations on the ranged side of things, customization has also been given a boost. Though so far I haven't seen anywhere near the weapon count of WotR, having said that it is in beta and will almost certainly be getting more content as the game develops. Nevertheless customizing the look of your character is still good. Capes, beards and helmets are all included as is the look of you clothes...I think.

Graphically the game is still pretty nice, I am not sure if it is as good as the previous game, but that is something YOU should make your mind up on. Although let it be said it certainly isn't bad!

There are issues with server drop outs and total game crashes, which one would hope to see ironed out when the final product is released. However I wouldn't hold your breath as these issues are a known problem on WotR and have so far been overlooked in every patch release.

In all honesty on a personal note I was hoping for a re-skin of War of the Roses with maybe a few new features chucked in, whilst seeing some of the bugs and glitches addressed. Unfortunately that was not the case, and instead of getting a very in depth, hand to hand combat game like it's predecessor, we were provided with a competitor to Chivalry for the people who have an ephemeral attention span, want a quick fix and nothing more. It does have some new features which are nice, but the core of the game is just poo.

For the discerning consumer out there, do youself a favour and give War of the Roses a try (and give it some time) or, if you want a quick fix go for Chivalry, but don't waste your hard earned cash on this sloppy execution of a game. For people wanting and expecting War of the Roses part 2, forget it, it is a completely different game. For those wanting a Chivalry emulator, snap this puppy up and spam until your hearts content.

In conclusion, a thoroughly disappointing game. Essentially it is all geared towards a fast paced, hack and slash game rather than the slower, more realistic fighting we came to love (and loathe) on WotR. Given time I am sure that improvements will be made, but addressing the core fighting mechanics is essential and unfortunately that is not going to happen.

3/10

reviewText:
TL;DR Review: THIS SHOULDN'T BE FOR SALE. DO NOT BUY, WASTE OF MONEY.

Real Review: This used to be my favorite game. I bought the base version back in October of 2013 and eventually wound up buying both the $30 and (now defunct) $120 upgrade. I was the first NA player to hit rank 60 and was ranked 5th in the list of earned exp upon the game's full release. This is a little bit of my War of the Vikings pedigree and I'm presenting it to you to prove that, when it comes to this game, I know what I'm talking about. I also like to brag.

Throughout this game's history it's had  many ups and downs. Unfortunately, there has never been as much of a down down as this current down. Its almost as though the last developer to work on this game had some sort of down... syndrome. Now while that little bit of sodium might make it sound like I'm some bitter oldtimer who's sh!tposting about the direction the game is headed in, please believe me when I say that I'm not. I've enjoyed a solid 975 of the 983 hours I've spent playing  this game - I've gotten my money's worth. The unfortunate thing about this game is that if you buy it today, you will  not  have the same experience that I did.

To illustrate why this is, I've created a very simple pros and cons list. While this list would have been massively different before the game's original dev team left in late 2014, the work of WotVs  most recent developer  has left the game in this very unfortunate state.

Pros:
none

Major Cons:
terrible hit detection (and the game is massively reliant upon hit detection)
frequent in-game crashes
dead player base (haven't seen more than 30 online in FOREVER, usually 0-10 online)
no single-player
slated for no further development

Minor Cons:
startup crashes (I've had to relaunch 8 or 9 times on multiple occasions)
terrible design choices (my opinion, arguable)
North Korean forum moderation (dissenting threads locked, terrible design choices militantly defended)


Now after reading that you might be thinking if this really is the current state of the game
date: why is it still being sold?" And to that question
recommended: I have no answer. From a moral perspective

reviewText:
Essentially like buying half a game, even for $25. It has some great charms and some VERY satisfying combat from time to time, but it face plants in so many areas that make it impossible to enjoy either of those. You will find: spawning issues, indecipherable hit boxes, striped down customization, infuriating bugs, a few balance issues , and an overall feeling of a lack of polish. All that is especially irritating for those coming off of War of the Roses and wondering where everything went.

And it’s a shame too, because War  of the Vikings is a game I genuinely WANT to be good. The potential is all there, I can almost see myself having a great time, but its cut off at the knees by large list of things that could have easily been prevented. It feels like a game that needs a few more months of dev. time, even after letting players PAY to test play it. The lower $25 price point is not enough to justify that kind of letdown, and that is what it is, a letdown.

A paid class with unique abilities (wielding spear and shield combined with a new special attack) breaks the game balance and drives the nail in WotVs coffin.
I cant recommend this game at this point in time

reviewText:
In short i am realy disapointed with War of The Vikings :(
I played the alfa, beta and bought the game before it was released. All the time i was saying to myself things will improve on launch, there is so much potential in the viking theme, they did so amazing job with War of The Roses ...

As a huge Mount and Blade cRPG and War of The Roses fan i can say ... War of The Viking is not good enough.
It lacks in many ways compared to older War of The Roses ... everything was made to be more simple - no reload mechanisms, no mounts, small maps with a lot of chokepoints, ... i would be able to accept War of The Viking as a lesser simplified version BUT i am not able to accept inredibly unresponsive combat system.

War of The Roses was a lot more tacticat game with incredible amount of variety.
If you love dueling, huge battles, tight combat system buy War of The Roses instead.

And yes TB inspired me to write my own opinion down.

reviewText:
The development team has been disbanded and the publishing company has killed the entire franchise. This game had an incredible amount of potential, and it has all been destroyed by horrible management, marketing and Battlefield 4 level network errors. A year ago, I would've recommended everyone purchase this game. 8 months ago I would have said if you enjoyed melee combat games, it's pretty good. Now, I can confidently say, it's simply a matter of time before the plug is pulled so to speak. Purchase War of the Vikings ONLY if you want to go down with the sinking ship. There is fun to be had and beauty to be admired, but it's all on borrowed time now. I'll miss this community, because in truth none of us know how much longer we'll have servers to play on.

TLDR;
Devs abandoned the game.
Publisher is notoriously profit over quality focused.
Game WILL be shut down soon, it's announced in the forums in a political jargon filled post.
Don't buy.

reviewText:
Ohh man this is so sad, i really love the third person brutality of this game, not many in the viking genre had these tence battles! and since im from Norway near the viking town Tønsberg i love playing the barbars! I sent Paradox message asking for current game statement since we had not heard from them awhile... then i got sad news back...

http://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/showthread.php?803911-Statement-regarding-the-War-franchise
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Statement regarding the War franchise
Greetings community!

We are writing you today to inform you what is happening with the War franchise, most importantly War of the Vikings but also its predecessor War of the Roses. This announcement has been some time in the making and has been no easy conclusion, yet we aim to be as transparent as possible. So, with no further ado, here is what is happening.
We are stopping sales of the Valhalla edition - effective immediately
All Valhalla owners will receive a large selection of Paradox Interactive's games on steam (added directly to their steam libraries), estimated value circa $800 as compensation. This will appear within a few days
Valhalla owners will also keep their Valhalla privileges - nothing will change here
War of the Vikings will see two patches to increase stability and solve major issues - after this we will cease patching and have no plans to support the game further through updates/fixes
Servers will continue to stay active until further notice
War of the Roses will see no further development
Why are we doing this? To put it simple and straight forward; We've looked at this from every single angle (that's why it's taken time for us to come to this conclusion) over and over and we just can't find a way where we can keep developing the games without operating at a loss. War of the Vikings did not live up to our expectations and we could not find a reasonable scenario where we could bring it up to par quality wise.

We have chosen to patch Vikings in order to bring it to a better state, so that current players can continue to enjoy what we have today with increased stability.

Sincerely,
The War Team
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I can understand its not cool to have a productive team working on a dead title... but there are so much you should have done before... is it like you guys are making a game without thinking or having the funding for a period of time after launch.. Patching and making your game baby shine!

Make the game F2P and add some cosmetics like beards etc. or maps or DLC stuff , seems like this game has alot of servers running. Its cool as H... when playing with friends so i dont get it, but that is why you are publishers and im not im sure ! Its really sad seeing this leave and hate that its called dead :(.

I think i will not support anymore of your Games from now on, i feel like this is a trending strategy.. seeing it more and more.

Next time, have your baby and feed it with content and care for it! dont tuckle it in a blanket with 2 patches and throw it in the bin and act like we wallet" dont understand whats going on ! Peace



Mspaint Out"

reviewText: War of the Vikings, despite bonus points for a wonderfully creative attempt to generate brand recognition for a niche game franchise, is essentially a dumbed down version of Roses, which in and of itself is a dumbed down version of Warband with some nice extra bells and whistles.  The only major upside to this game over its predecessor is that Vikings is not horribly imbalanced due to a series of progressively more destructive patches by the ever so responsive developers.  Though not as casual as Chivalry, Vikings displays how great game mechanics can be essentially ruined in order to appeal to a more general audience of casual gamers.  Hopefully, as this pattern continues we'll see an increased push for hardcoar game developers to make the move to mobile platforms.  After all, because casual games sell far better than any niche PC game, they are obviously better, rite?

reviewText:
Review at 2014/04/14 (Onde day before release).
Current patch: 0.9.9
My specs: I7 920 oc @3,4Ghz, GTX 470 1Gb, 8 GB RAM @1600 Mhz. 1920x1080.

¡BAD ENGLISH DETECTED!

//// v1.0 version ////

I had a boost of 15-20 fps. Now I can run the game with all textures on high and antialising at 60 fps or more. Shadows must be disabled as well as the cloth effects (physics).

//////////////////////////

General description:
- It isn't the same as WoTR. Some people prefer one, some people prefer the other one. This is more dynamic, and fast paced game with less variables and easier handling.
- Hard at start if you have not played M&B or WoTR but either way is a challenging game.
- Smaller maps than WoTR to increase game speed, but usually with more ways to flank the enemy.
- Beautiful art, graphics and music.

Cons:
- Unbalance with some weapons. Some day one, some day another. And some spammeable and lammer game mechanics can annoy you sometimes as in the majority of games.
- Bad servers (Multiplay) and ATM you can only rent them, so you cannot make a dedicated server in your own machine.
- Lag related issues. The ping is fine in Europe but as I said, the bad server performance is ruining the game. (I have to say that this may not be directly the fault of the developers of WOTV)
- Game performance is worse than before. For me, of course. Now I have to run the game in 'low' settings except the textures to achieve 35-65 FPS. (My specs in top).
- Gameplay bugs. The shields don't work perfectly, some crappy animations, etc.

Pros:
- The game will be supported for a long time. Solving issues, balancing, adding a lot of content, etc.
- Good customization level and options, and this will increase with time.
- The game can be really enjoyable regardless of winning or losing, etc. but you have to take your time to master the playstyle. So be patient if someone instakill you every time, or if you can't hit/parry anybody.
(That is fine, you will be good in less time than in WoTR. It is easier to play for newcomers, but still hard to master).
- External anticheat system. This was a very great thing.
- You can sprint :D
- Cosmetics only. The item's stats are equal in a sword that costs 320 coins to another that costs 30000. That allow new players to play in the same conditions as a veteran. It just will look ugliest or more beautiful.

Conclusions:

If you don't have patience, this may not be your game. Neither if you expect be the king  in your first match.

If you can deal with some bugs, lammers and archers (I won't lie you, sometimes is an arrow fest) you will have good moments.

I approve this game, it could be better but i'm sure it will get better. It's just a matter of time.

////////////////////////////////////  VERY OLD  ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

Great game in BETA stage. I think it's a logic evolution of its predecessor (War of the Roses).
The combat speed has been increased and the animations are much more smooth and realistic. The learning curve is long, its a hard and kinda frustrating game at the begining. (If you come from WoTR the learning curve will be much more soft).

FAQ: It's the same as WoTR? - No, it isn't. The evolution is really tangible; improved graphics, physics, animations, (for now) balance. New weapons, fight styles, attacks, habilities and game mechanics.

In my opinion it is less difficult to play than WoTR and more satisfactory. For now, all the weapons are pretty well balanced, you can win a fight with all of them, really the acquired skill and teamplay are your best friends.

Pros in beta stage:
- Really enjoyable and funny. (For now without xp and customizing system)
- In my case without performance issues since the alpha stage. (GTX 470)
- The developers are there listening and answering to the players.
- When you win a close battle is really satisfactory.

Cons in beta stage:
- Third party anti-cheat system isn't enabled yet so there are a lot of speedhackers.
(It will be applied in a few weeks).
- Due to the pre-release stage, the difficulty, and the casual" players that has only played a few minutes
date: the servers are usually not full
recommended: and in Europe is difficult to play passed 2:00 a.m.\n- few little maps and game modes for now
hoursPlayed: a little repetitive.\n\nCya and sorry for my english!"

reviewText:
Got this game on sale even though everything I heard was bad. Game is actually pretty fun. I will be breif and break it down.

CONS
Not many servers
Issues with lag if you have bad internet like me (Australia)
Steep learning curve
Tutorial does not work
Somes weapons appear at first use to be useless and are hard to learn
Buying cosmetic upgrades cost signifcantly more coins than what is earned for winning a match

PROS
Not many servers - the small community play often and well together because of this
Graphically impressive
Great customisation
Levelling is faster than expected
Other than lag/skill; no distinction between players of varying levels/ranks
All upgrades/higher tier weapons are cosmetic
Combat is challenging though fun
(So far imo) everyone playing has been friendly and welcoming to new people like me
Funny deaths happen
No Chivalry ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t 360 kills

I know this game got a lot of bad ♥♥♥♥ and rep, but it's quite playabvle and indeed a lot of fun with a few people.
I highly recomend that when it comes on sale to grab a copy.

TLDR; If you like vikings and picking from an assortment of beards, had fun with mount and blade but want something more visceral then get this game.

10/10 Would viking and split skulls again.

EDIT: As of the 20/1 The recent update has made the game a lot more stable to play and less laggy with better hit detection. I'm surprised they brought out anotehr patch however I'm glad to see some improvement.

reviewText: This is a tough sell to recommend or not do so, as both sides have some decisive quality to them. While authentic in its setting and certainly in the right place with its concept, execution in War of the Vikings isn't on point yet to become enjoyable. With disjointed character animations and imprecise flailing, no matter how careful the input, the finesse it wants to achieve for melee driven combat and that which it allows with awkward positioning patterns are not on the same wavelength yet. It's not in any sense irreparable, but so far this is a game that only veterans will pick up, wrestle through to handle and subsequently crush any new blood that may have an inkling towards it; creating an aversion where it should promote a community.\n\nIt's not the position in which you stand
date: but the direction that you face."\n\nEDIT: Since this review
recommended: the game has seen numerous patches between 5GB and 13GB. Downright insulting. I haven't seen poor optimization like that since Vista."

reviewText: I have been playing this with my girlfriend for hours a day. The only other game we play is left for dead and have played that for years. Lately we have not played left for dead too much to focus on Vikings. I hope this game is updated soon as I spent 29 bucs for the special upgrade. I just like the feeling of killing and conquering in this. Their are many different strategies and everyone will find their favorite be it sword, axe, archer etc. I do not have any other experience to compare it to as i have not played Chivalry or others. I have received my moneys worth and if they can expand this into pirates, and other eras like Greeks, Romans etc will give it added life. Give it a shot, I just love the show Vikings and the historical aspects of it. I gave it a try when it was free for a weekend and you can join right in and play. It will take you a few hours or more to get things down but believe me slaughtering your opponent or taking down 2 or 3 solo is a thrill. You also will get a little tense, and aches and pains from the stress of combat. Much more so then Left for dead I can tell you.

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY! Read on! This is an alpha and full release review.

I wouldn't go near this game until it has been released fully.
Still keen? Expect 5gig+ patches every two weeks or monthly. I have downloaded over 20gig of patches in the last 8 weeks for stuff all changes, with that sort of patch volume I'd expect big changes or more content, neither were apparent. When you ask the devs whats up with the huge patches you will have the question removed from the forum, truly awesome work devs.
The player base is tiny, being an Oceanic gamer it is even smaller, not even remotely worth it.
My opinion; stick with War of roses, do not give these guys a dime until the finished product is out, they don't deserve it.
FYI; take note of when the positive reviews for this game happened, very few people are happy with the state of play in 2014.

POST FULL VERSION LAUNCH.
The game is still garbage, the devs continue to push out 5gig patches every couple of weeks to add one or two swords or tweak a class. The game is a joke, the balance is getting worse, the combat clunkier, the range combat is a waste of time. The devs could care less about finishing as they could about adding more DLC for kids to buy. How you can release DLC less than a month after an official launch and not give to preaccess and alpha is disgusting and should tell you all you need to know about these devs and what they think of the consumer.

War of Roses was/ is a better game; armor, range, better levels, mounted combat. Its just better (yes even with its current balance).
War of vikings; waste of money, the devs should of kept working on roses, this is the same game with different textures, a clunkier-crappier combat system and none of the above mentioned features. GG fapshark

reviewText:
I am not going to lie guys, this game has serious problems. Being a Paradox fan I was very happy when I found out that they have decided to make a game with Vikings. Having played War of the Roses I have to admit that the experience is far worse than I have expected. The weapons, life bar and stamina are creating difficulties to newer players as two hits, or even one can prove fatal. You find that you remain without stamina quite often whilst you wonder how your foe manages to strike so many times...the worst though is the defence mechanics. The shield or sword/axe parry has a 'limited' function as you cannot defend yourself too much as the stamina bar gowes down really fast and it doesn't cover too much of an area.

It is worth mentioning that whilst in War of the Roses you earn a decent amount of money with which you can upgrade and customize yourself in War of the Vikings you have to put some money becasue after a match you'll find that you haven't earned even for a new weapon.

Lastly, I am very disappointed about the fact that I have to close down certain features of my antivirus and start Steam on Administrator mod if I want to play it as the AntiCheat fails to start and I believe that is why many of the servers are now empty (far too many errors and bugs).

reviewText:
Its still beta, so many things might ( and hopefully will ) change, but for now:

improvements over WotR - no bleeding (wouldnt make sense anyway, you go down in 2 hits)

worse than WotR - only 4 melee weapons, that seem to have same reach(no matter wheter 2h or 1h), some throwings and bow...with exception of spear you attack right, left or overhead, with perk you can dodge attack...thats all, no charge, no shield bash, nothing...therefore fight goes like 1) wait for opponent to swing (charged attack takes like 3s), or 2) SPAM...and also you have instakill one hit button, but it takes ages to use, you might luckily kill, or unluckily die..
So far no appereance customization- well you can paint your shield and switch helmet, but thats about it, all helmets have same stats, no armor change...you will meet many clones of yours.
Everybody attacks same speed (no armor dependant spd attack, weapon types have same speed, no combat styles)

You can also SPRINT...it means you run faster WITHOUT WEAPON and also you can be tripped while sprinting- aka replaces horses, only slower, more dangerous and not usable in combat.

Ranged combat: like in chivalry and wotr many guys didn´t have guts to go melee or failer miserably in it, so they grabbed
bow or crossbow, tried to kill you while you weren´t moving-  ressurecting teammates, or when you were bandaging yourself- aka less than no skill neccessary, and when things got personal, they ran away -_-.
In wotv it´s even worse- when you walk slowly against bow user, you get hit xxxx times, so you die. When you sprint against them, you cannot do anything, to not get hit, tripped and killed on 2nd or 3rd arrow, because you can´t block (well you can use 1/4 of your perk, so it will save you from stun->death by bow, but you still get to the fight with 30-50% hp.
With another perk you can throw anything you want...just stick to it, this game might be about melee, but is not. Melee in this stinks terribly...

And I know its ment to be fantasy, but heavily armored warrior killed by spam knive ? Really ?

As I wrote, it might change, but so far I just cant recommend it to anyone...unless you are one of those archer guys...

reviewText:
Dear Paradox,

Seriously. What the f*ck? Are you really going to charge $25 for an arguably unplayable game that you no longer support? The hit detection in this game is worse than what you would see in an 85 year old hooker. And when I do actually land a hit the weapons are so poorly tuned my jaw drops a little each time. Then again Vikings were well known for being able to be take 5 spear stabs or 3 flaming arrows directly to the face before dying.

There are only 1-2 partially filled rooms. The majority of the people admit it sucks but keep playing because it apparently wasn't always like this. The rest have assimilated the crap mechanics into their very being and exploit it to tank strikes that should be kills and land hits that look like they missed by a mile.

Fix your game.

reviewText: This game isn't anything like the preview shows. It's a lot of team stacking and glitchy hit boxes. I've played MUCH MUCH better games of this style. My biggest problem is the swinging/blocking is really sloppy. Literately have my sword/axe slice through someone's head and it does nothing to them, then they swing back and are 5-10 feet away and insta kill me. It's very generic, battle is repetitive. Usually you have one guy running around with 50+ kills owning everyone on the map while everybody else barely makes it to 10 kills if they are lucky. But the game killer for me was having my weapon hit people then it not register, and only to get counter struck from 5-10 feet away and insta gibbed. Mount and Blade has better game mechanics. I don't agree with this idea of buying a game before it's anywhere near finished and praying it was worth the money upon release either.

reviewText:
I've been a big fan of Paradox, and the games that they have taken part in, since Mount and Blade. And one of the things that I've enjoyed most is the continued evolution of deep, intricate combat systems that truly reward the player for knowing where to strike at opponent (observing armored vs. less armored locations on the body, head shots, etc.), cultivating the skill to aim for those locations with various weapon systems, and all the while providing a solid parry/attack system.

As a fan, I felt that I owed it to the company to reign in my initial reactions and not say anything terribly negative about the game until its release. Indeed, among my friends, I even suggested that they might enjoy the game. It was beta, after all, and certain to offer a great deal of improvements.

The game has been released now though, and I can't help but to express some disappointment.

Let me first give the positive bits though.

The game offers a fun exchange of quick, hack and slash violence. There is some skill involved in learning to properly parry incoming attacks and, well, anyone considering such a game will almost certainly enjoy reveling and shouting out a taunt that heals yourself while you stand amid a heap of your enemy's writhing corpses.  This, and other similar scenarios, are certainly rewarding.

But that is about where the rewards end.

The complexity of Paradox and Fat Shark's War of the Roses has largely been discarded in favor of faster pacing and more arcade-like play that departs somewhat from the skill-based" combat that is advertised in this franchise. Worse yet
date: the technical problems within War of the Roses were ignored
hoursPlayed: and allowed to continue to be a problem within War of the Vikings.\n\nIn War of the Vikings
voteText: armor is all but meaningless
helpfulPercent: with the "Champion"  classes offering only a slight increase to the number of times you can be hit (in comparison to the two other classes of "Warrior" and "Skirmisher")  whereas in War of the Roses armor could entirely ward off enemy blows unless they struck weak spots in that armor's design.\n\nWeapons too have been simplified. Whereas War of the Roses offered dozens of options
votesHelpful: each with some variation in speed
votesTotal: damage
votesFunny: reach
commentsCount: armor penetration
column16: etc.
column17: War of the Vikings instead offers you a two handed axe
column25:
and a long bow.

That is it.

After extended periods of play you do unlock coins that you may use to purchase variations of these weapons
column27: these variations are purely aesthetic. There is no variation in their performance - they just look cool. Similarly
column28: through advancing in level and gaining coins
column29: you may also unlock different color schemes for your clothing
column31: or paint new designs on your shields.  By comparison
column32: painting your shield was something you did at any level you desired in War of the Roses - unlocking a new shield with new stats that impacted how you played was something you could be rewarded with through play.\n\nBeyond this over-simplification of play
column33: I also find that lag - though much improved since alpha and beta play - has more of an impact on play than in near any other multiplayer game I have ever played. In most games
column34: latency will impact the player who is lagging most severely. Sometimes other players may see them skip or whatever
column35: but usually it doesn't impact them horribly.  In War of the Vikings
column37: the fallout seems to result in more global rammifications.  Players near another player with high ping
column39: will also skip about or "teleport". Their weapon reaches become unpredictably long or short
column40: attacks will impact before/after it appears they should
column41: and your own attacks may pass right through them. In a game that is purely multiplayer
column42: this is entirely unacceptable. Smooth play resulting from good servers and good coding should be a priority.\n\nAll of these were problems
column44: in the previous game in the franchise. It is disappointing to see that these technical problems
column46: have been ignored if not intensified.\n\nMy overall impression is that the developers of War of the Vikings paid far too much attention to the critics who had compared their previous title
column48: to Chivalry.\n\nInstead of listening to their fans and providing us with a complex combat system and richly rewarding level progression system
column49: we have been given a watered down
column50: arcade-like game desperately seeking to capture the faster and more brutal play of another franchise. And
column53: offering nothing of the visceral immersion

reviewText: At first, i thought this game was pretty good. It still is gameplaywise for the most part. My big issue with this game is the f*cked progression system. In 20min i earned ~10,000xp (pretty high on the rankings, definitly top half). After playing, i went to buy new gear, and to my horror i had only earned 900 gold (barely enough to buy a throwing knife). War of the Roses had it right, you earned more money and there wasnt a need to unlock equipment by level, only gold. The game is fun, but unless you have tens or hundreds of hours to devote to this game, you wont progress AT ALL.\nNOTE: About the progression, my points are invalid because ALL THE WEAPONS ARE ONLY RESKINS\nNOTE 2: BUY War of the Roses: Kingmaker or Mount and Blade Warband instead.

reviewText: Great game when I first started out, it was Alpha, issues were expected. Beta came around, we still had the same issues, but we got some new features, a couple more issues arose, and we went along with it. Full release, none of the issues were fixed still, random crashes, packet loss, bad hitboxes, lag issues, the works. We got some more new content, broken, and at this point we weren't fooled. Don't buy this game, they are just packing out dlc at this point trying to get people to buy a broken game that they keep putting a shine on. Save your money, take it from someone who has played, it's not worth the end disappointment.

reviewText:
First, I don't write reviews.

The game can be incredibly fun and addictive, I will give it that. Combat is fast, graphics are nice, and it is damn satisfying to murder an enemy player with an axe. That being said it has a long road ahead of itself in order to deliver a worthy end result.

In its current state the game plays well enough. Random crashes, disconnects, and the trouble with actually swinging your weapon the direction you want make this game frustrating on a higher level of play. There are some hit detection issues along with several simple wtf" moments where lag will have your weapon/arrows go straight through an enemy player. These issues have NOT stopped me from putting 20 hours into the game though.

If this game was going for 5-10 dollars I could recommend this game. Its worthy a romp but purely multiplayer games like this need logevity to keep the community (and servers) full enough to enjoy it."

reviewText:
I cracked some skulls, chanted some chants,  Kumbayah'd with the best of them...       and flailed about madly until my axe connected!... too bad it had to connect more than once... and the other guy was a tad better at flailing than I was..

and that was just during the free weekend..  I then bought the game and became a figurehead of the community!   I'm that one they regret meeting on a cold day in a dark alley in the dead of night...    on the forums... and should you be unlucky enough to locate my various posts(This being one of them ;p) I'm sure you will see why!



As for the game itself, EXPECT TO DIE A BIT when you first join as it is a bit more 'skill based' than most games you find nowadays..   But my god.. throughout those deathstreaks you shall relish each and every crunch and slash and squish or (if lucky) that altogether knee shaking, awe inspiring, gasp producing, 'stop and listen to that incredible sound', HNNNNNNNNGGGGGGG inducing, glorious  SCCCHHHHHLLLUUURRRRRPPPP *plop, thud*that occurs from your axe, sword, pigsticker, or bow connecting in just such a way as to remove the enemies skull from his shoulders.

It is early access Beta but it is in an entirely playable state and I have reccomended it to many of my friends and quite a few of us enjoy long walks on the blood soaked beaches under the moonlight under the banner of the Red moose, or Purple bear!(Either of which = best squad)    The community is on the smaller side, but you always can find a match to hop into at a moments notice, or should you join an empty lobby, odds are you'll be fighting with a group in a few minutes( less than 5 minutes seemed to be average for me on an empty server)   AND the added perk of the smaller tighter community.. is you will know when that 'Bad @ss archer' joins in, or if you are lucky/unlucky enough(depending on perspective) to see those glorious words   'Oh lord... Tagg... why did you join THIS lobby?' which means I have arrived, and You Lucky sir or Madam, can play with ME!         and hilarity/madness shall ensue!   of this I swear.

Oh! And for you non agressive types, they offer the use of the dagger's special 'kick' ability, or the pigsticker's 'Push' ability to bring about the very first base jumpers in history!!( Too bad they forgot their parachutes!)

TL;DR       HHHNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNGGGGGGG     Vikings, battle, Glory, Honor, Valhalla, schluurrrp *plop thud* 'HEADSHOT',   Amazing Community, 'Tagg, Y U DO DIS?',    did you really read all of ^^?  ... you poor gullible person...   Dont you know to always search for a TL;DR in a wall of text?     10 outta 10 and it aint even released a progression/customization system yet(Due in an update some time this month) in which case it will get a 101 out of 100  (Yeah... its that good.. it takes caps and breaks them.. much like arrows and kneecaps, and adventuring days ending)


... See you in Valhalla!   *Salutes*

I love this style of game - War of the Roses got me into it and I followed up by getting Vikings, which is worth getting if you like the taste of blood on the battlefield.

This game does need a bit of 'tweeking' to finish it off properly, but I would encourage people to get it, especially if it's on special as we need more warriors in the field - In Australia/NZ would be nice.

reviewText:
This game had so much potential, it had implemented some mechanics that gave it the chance to be so much fun. But then, they decided, lets limit that fun. Warriors cannot sprint without putting their weapon on their backs, for some reason, this was implemented, i am assuming to stop people from sprinting into combat swinging? but that couldn't be it, because that would add so much fun to the game.
But, probably the worst decision that was made, was to add an energy bar, i guess it is to stop people from swinging a lot, but that's what people wanted from this game, they wanted that fast paced action packed feeling, only to be greeted with absurdly unrealistic limitations. I want to have to block 15-20 swings in a 10 second fight, i want that thrill, that rush, the feeling one might expect from being a viking. But instead we are given a slow game, that makes it feel like we are all terribly hung over warriors, decades past our prime swinging heavy sticks, losing our breath after just a bare few swings. gone are the days warriors trained to endure i guess.

I just feel massively let down by this game, i thought it was going to be what war of the roses almost was before it was drenched in honey, making combat slow and boring. Although, the game might have changed? i haven't really been able to play it to test since a few months after it came out, considering how no one plays the game anymore. Its all a massive shame, i had high hopes, now i guess all i can do is wait for mount and blade 2, and hope they don't destroy that too, by catering to the slow of block.

did the designers just not want to do new weapons? power strike was awesome, if a 2nd is made, and they keep the energy bar, lets hope they make it so that it only gets drained by sprinting and power strike, its too short a bar, and recovers too slowly for it to be used for everything.

reviewText:
Fun when it works; sadly, that is not often.  Most glaring issue right now is the random lock-ups that last 2-3 seconds every 10 minutes or so.  You are also de-synced from the server for a few additional seconds afterwards.  More than likely you will be dead by the time the game resyncs.  The spawning system also needs work.  The game tries to spawn you right next to a fight which occasionally results in you getting instantly hacked down by a sea of enemies or vice-versa when an enemy spawns in the midst of your team.  You can't pick where you want to spawn either.  On top of this there are still Crash to Desktop issues.  In fact, I'm writing this review now after just having a random CTD in the middle of match for the umpteenth time.
Although this game is supposed to a spiritual successor to War of the Vikings, a lot of good features were removed.  No execution animations, no armor choices, no attack styles (ie swing faster but less damage), no bleeding/burning, no difference in piercing, blunt, slashing damage, etc etc etc

Hopefully these issues will be fixed with in time.  I hate to say it since the game could use more players, but avoid paying full price for this game for now.

reviewText:
Summary: Although a good concept, War of the Vikings is fundamentally flawed. Is historical credibility is appalling, the game mechanics perform badly, it is not an approachable game for a newcomer or casual player, and there is no good motivation to continue playing it.

Full review:

Although it might first appear as an historical title, War of the Vikings fails miserably in this regard. Weapons include 15th century daggers, 16th century pikes, and so on, but miss out on many period weapons (such as seaxes, after which the Saxons were named!). Armour is worse, with horned helmets, feathered headgear and armours from the middle-east. There are no historical battle sites and maps are simply generic locations... including epic towering monastaries or Skyrim-esque glaciers. And the in-game warriors can do lots of other non-historical things, all the way from running around impaled with multiple javelins through to techno-dancing. Although there is no obligation for developers to stick to fact, the flights of fantasy in this game really detracts from the historical immersion.

But War of the Vikings does not make up for it with game play. The mechanics are random in places, with weapons simply passing through without damage, or you can often do more damage with the haft of the axe than the head of it. Server glitches and crashes are common place, even on sparsely-populated servers. This level of unreliability (even on ping-limited servers, using good computers with good connections) is extremely frustrating. Even the graphics, which are okay, are really demanding on even good computer systems. You really need a first-class Internet connection and top-notch machine with a superb frame rate to even contemplate this title.

From the perspective of someone who has never played other hand-to-hand combat games, the learning curve on War of the Vikings is brutal. There is scant documentation (only a single splash screen showing the key presses) and a woefully inadequate tutorial. There is no single-player game to train you up nor are there any matched-skill servers. The community comprises mostly elite veterans and you can expect to spend a lot of time staring at the spawn-in screen.  While there are some exceptions, I have found a disproportinate level of arrogance and contempt in games. Even the so-called friendly clans" take delight in abusing inexperienced players.

Finally
recommended: there is no motivation to play. The weapons/armour are all equal in combat value. This is okay in terms of balance
hoursPlayed: but for a modest amount of playtime
voteText: you can get any loadout and perks. Thus upgrades are not an incentive to play. The ability to purchase expensive-looking clothes and capes might appeal to some
helpfulPercent: but it is not a huge motivation to persevere with being cut down time after time. The Steam achievements totally lack imagination and are mostly way beyond the reach of the average player
votesHelpful: who just wants to recreate the Viking/Saxon battle experience.\n\nAlthough there are some nice touches (for example the use of Old English/Icelandic for the voices and a wonderful soundtrack)
votesTotal: this game is frustrating and quickly becomes tedious. Out of a love of this era of history
votesFunny: I have stuck with it and have trained hard at it

reviewText:
War of the Vikings is not the kind of game a lot of people expect it to be. It's hard, the mechanics take some getting used to and it takes hours and hours to get to a point where you can confidently head out on to the battlefield, but that is what drew me so deep into the heart of the game.

I am glad I hopped in so early in the development, because I came into this as an absolute beginner. I've never played Mount & Blade, I've never played War of the Roses. It was a completely new system of combat and holy ♥♥♥♥ did it kick my ♥♥♥. I was next to useless for at least 10 hours. It was frustrating... I would run into a group of guys and get hacked to death over and over, they were so much better than me... but I kept with it.

Early on, the game had no reviving system, no way to heal teammates, it was just barebones fighting and it was chaotic. Having no one to coordinate with, it's really easy to get overwhelmed by opponents. Any fool with an two handed axe can kill you if he can get a good swing in. Death is waiting behind every rock, every corner and you can't escape it. You had to learn to put up a fight.

The game is much more finely tuned after many patches and fixes along the way, but it still has it's share of bugs and glitches. Most times I find that the team markers (blue/green or red highlights) don't work as intended. It can be quite easy to mistake an ally without a highlight for an untagged enemy and you are going to pay for it with -XP based on damage dealt.  Team kills are a common occurance, as should be expected in a close quarters brawl with axes and swords flailing about wildly. That's where practice comes in.

The way weapons work in this game is brilliant, in my opinion. All purchasable weapons are nothing more than just skins, meaning that anyone with the basic rusty longsword is just as effective as someone with an expensive sword. This forces a set and controlled balance to the combat. I am not talking 100% balance here... I just mean that you know everyone else is just as dangerous as you. Technically. Proper positioning and footwork play a huge factor in winning a fight.

While some aspects are balanced, some things are not quite there yet... Ask anyone playing right now, the Two-Handed axe and heavy armour are the most common sight in-game. Anyone good enough can one shot your head clean off and just continue to steam roll through hordes of enemies, lopping heads like weed whacker in a field of dandelions. It can be incredibly discouraging for new players to join a server with veteran players.

A skilled player understands the mechanics to a point where all they have to do is watch for animation clues and they will be able to parry, block, or dodge just about anything. A new player will most likely be slaughtered while paired against a skilled player, but not always. One mistake is all it takes for either side to gain an edge. That being said, most new players, after finding the F key is a special attack that generally kills, will spam the hell out that move, along with dodge attacks. This is not a good idea and while it may score you some satisfying kills, it's a good way to get yourself killed while you are stuck in the animations of the special.

The thing about this game is that it is punishing. Most players don't want to invest the time to acquire the skills required in this game to be any good at all. You have to push through the relentless deaths, either by enemies or allies alike, you can't let the game make you give up. Don't come into it thinking you are going to be hot ♥♥♥♥ right from the get go and then start raging when you die. No one wants to hear you complain endlessly in game about how ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t the mechanics are, only because you don't understand them. Yes. Shields are hard to use and they do need to work on that. Yes, parry delay is a thing and it frustrates the hell out of everyone even sort of competetive. It is a frustration generating, rage inducing, all-out brawl and nothing is going to change that, you just have to learn to hold your own and work together with the team. That is what brings me back, battle after battle.

So, If you are like me and really enjoy a good competetive challenge, you're not afraid to put a little effort in learning the mechanics and are looking for a game with a generally supportive community, I would pick up a copy and try it out for myself. No review is going to convey to you how a game really feels, you have to experience it for yourself.

reviewText:
Fun to PVP in conquests for a bit - think capture the flag but with a viking twist, at least it gives you some direction and goal in the game but the game gets old and very quickly. The FREE weekend was all I needed to know that there is no point in buying this game. Awful nice that the developers did that, otherwise I would be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ having spent money to play a game like this, like I did with NETHER - biggest mistake ever, but I digress.

The Deathmatches are stupid really, run around trying to kill your enemy and the first team to 100 wins.  Spawn points aren't protected and you can end-up spawning at the same location as an enemy and I found it quite common to go on 4-5 insta-death spawns because of this. Mechanics are sluggish at best and special moves leave you wanting much more.

Don't even get me started on teammates that don't revive, or archers that never switch to melee when the need arises.

Great to see the game visuals for free, but other than that there is nothing new to see here - move along

reviewText: Wheres the yellow sideways thumb?  Though I can't really recommend this game now, it may turn into something rather entertaining.  Pretty much the easiest way to get damage and kills is by playing archer(so lots of archers), plus the maps are set as such that there are only a few paths to follow.  Meaning you have to run these corridors of arrow-y death, no flanking allowed.  Oh there might be a secret back path, but there's usually only 1 and it's not secret.  Plus the random peeps with mega-scores and extra-zip in their step.  Maps are small.  Combat is rather floaty with no weight to it.  A two hander swings about the same as a one hander which has about the same feel as a javelin.  Visually it is nice.\n\nThere are other games out there of this genre and they are all quite similar, so why would you play more than one?  This game needs to be something special to stand out, and currently, it just isn't.

reviewText:
There's a lot of promise here, but the mechanics are insanely buggy or just poorly implemented.

Weapon reach is not intuitive.  It would seem that different swings would have different hitboxes.  Swinging left-right hits a wider arc than up-down, right?  Well, no.  It appears that all of your melee attacks only strike directly in front of you.  Also, they have a height component.  Regardless of the animation, your attack hitboxes aren't a very large rectangle.

Now, either related to the poor attack hitboxes, or just buggy hit detection, or just bad lag compensation, I've literally clipped INSIDE of people and been unable to hit them with melee.  Then moments later, swing at someone as they sprinted away and got them three steps out.  I've blocked and had attacks blocked by a shield from directly behind.

I couldn't even play half an hour before I finally gave up in frustration.  Do not play.

reviewText:
I am revisiting my review one more time now that the developers have officially called it quits.

I had high hopes for this game. When I bought it back in alpha it was incredibly fun, well balanced, and compelling. I poured hours into the game and became one of the best players. For a while I thought that this game had a real future and the potential for serious competitive play...because the skill curve was so high.

It saddens me...quite sincerely...to see that the game has failed. The concept was beautiful and amazingly fun. I wish it had been better...but alas, it was not to be.

The developers made a few changes before the game went into beta and it changed the game's feelilng. I think it was to appeal to a wider audience...but they made it 'easier'. It's hard to describe. If you couple this with their growing latency problems (ping was a huge factor), and the fact that they refused to listen to the community about balance crippled the game. I recall making a suggestion, seeing it implemented, and then having it taken away because of people whining.

The problem that doomed the game from the start is that for a certain niche of players, it was amazing. In fact...it was stunning. The problem was that the skill curve was very high and most new players were destroyed over and over until they quit (or until the developers decided to change things).

By the time the game was released, it was essentially waiting for the nail in the coffin. The community, realizing that the game was not turning out like they wanted, abandoned it. I stopped playing...and the rest of my clan, the best clan in the game, left. We never really played again.

Such is the story of War of the Vikings. A game with great promise marred by broken mechanics and bad netcode. I wish there was a way to go back in time and revert the game ot the alpha. If that was the case, I would return and play again...but I know it won't happen.

My advice. Don't bother. The game has died.

reviewText:
DONT BUY.
At first it seemed like a decent fast-paced close combat game to buy and also for those who like the whole viking universe it would seem like a decent purchase, but it's deffinetly NOT.

In the early stages it was OK, but still the price was way too high for what the game has to offer:
-No singleplayer campaign.
-A sorry excuse for a tutorial.
-Fast action multiplayer matches, but then again there are very few modes and they are all similar.
-Few different customizable classes (they actually dont feel like a 'rock-paper-scissor' balance, they are just the same garbagge with different colour).

And now the things about the game the developers didn't intend but happened anyway:
-Constant balance issues.
-Constant server crashes from early alpha to the present.
-Few active servers and most of them in USA (for us playing from another country, the lagg makes this game more interesting).
-Very poor technichal support (just look at the dates from the patch fixes).
-Overral very lazy design in any aspect.

In short terms, this game was a rip-off. I sincerely feel like the team that made this game invested little to no effort in making it and took quite a bunch of money to run away with.
It is the first time i feel robbed and violated because of a steam purchase, but i guarantee that at least with this Fatshark company, it's going to be the last.

Never buy from them, don't even accept any of their games for free.

reviewText:
This is a difficult one for me, to be honest.  I played a good long while in the beta and was at first, quite impressed with what they had.  However, I was expecting...well, more at release.

Yes, there are bugs and hit detection issues, those are all true but I can push past that.  What I couldn't look past were the very, very weak game modes that ended up hurting any excitement I might have had while playing.  There's just...nothing worth fighting for in this game.

reviewText:
This game has alot of negative reviews, played it from early access and it was very good to see an early access sucess. Seems those are rare.
I think most of the negative reviews come from people who played War of the Roses (previous game), I haven't played it tho, to be completely honest I didn't even know it existed before playing War of the Vikings, so my view on it might be different because of that.
I really enjoyed this game, played quite a bit and to me it's a pretty cool solid medieval combat game. I think the berserker patch ruined it a little bit tho. Berserkers seem off, seem like they are kind of those uninvited guests that everyone has to deal with because their mechanics are really different from the core challenge and mechanics of the game. Still is a solid pick in my humblest opinion.

I haven't played War of the Roses so take this with a grain of salt, but from what I've seen and read, if you come from that game this is apparently a downgrade and simplified version which you probably wont like.
Ignoring that fact tho and seeing it as a standalone tittle, this is pretty fun! Plus if you like the whole Viking nord aesthetic and feel, for sure!
Also bear in mind that the community is for the most part dead at this point sadly. Haven't played it in a while, but it already was the case, there is still a couple full-ish servers most of the time, but don't expect a large community.

reviewText:
Compared to WotR and other games of this gengre, this game has close to nothing to offer. Laggy servers and an incredible amount of bugs make this game barely playable.

Given that you use a shield, somebody is going to hack your ankles to the death. Parries also work ~75% of the time. Hit trading is very common, which also makes countering a special attack frustrating.

Weapons are barely balanced. The whole combat system revolves around two players running in circles until the game somehow allows the other player bypass the enemy's parry.

Customization and coin prices are but a joke. An average full length" game would yield ~300 coins

reviewText:
Let me start off with a little information of the game. This is you're classic style hand to hand combat game, which you do not see very many of in the first place, and usually when you do many people get it wrong and turns out like crap.

Now then lets speak of War of the Vikings, it can suprisingly be a very fun game, that is if you are fairly good at it, which actually takes alot longer then you would expect before you get used to the controls, unless you have played War of the Roses. The graphics are great and the maps are well created for that time period. The weapons are what you would expect from the viking culture from, 1h 2h axes, shields, swords such as the Famous Ulfberht, and throwing weapons and bows. And alot of this plays well with a somewhat balanced system of playability.

Now yes I have said that it so far is a good game, but let me give you a few reasons as to why this game is not yet" worth the $25 price tag that in my opinion is far overpriced. Now i am unsure as to if this game is still alpha beta or is actually released yet because it basically states the game is finished

reviewText:
A lot of bugs that have been pointed out since Early Access still have not been fixed.
Playerbase is pretty low, meaning that new players will always get into the same games as veterans.
Balancing issues that are ignored by the devs. (some ranged weapons can take your HP down to 10% in one hit)

Performance has been tweaked a couple of times but still isn't optimal.
If you're looking for a game with comparable combat, I'd suggest Mount and Blade instead.

I really regret spending money on this.

reviewText: The best thing about this game is if you play it for free during this weekend you'll also know exactly how Chivalry Medieval Combat plays: That is, by running back and forth swinging while hoping you'll get lucky to land more hits than your opponent does and hoping you don't accidentally kill too many of your allies when they're close to the action.\n\nThere is little to no skill or learning any kind of mechanic involved unless you're an archer who has to aim. Just hold left mouse for a second and release to swing. Special moves" are activated with a single button press and are just great ways to get yourself killed because they're really just standard-issue slow-but-powerful attacks. That's it. Oh
date: there's also the now prerequisite XP system for hitting your enemies
hoursPlayed:
and finishing them off (by just attacking them when they're on the ground and have a “Finish” label over them) that's stuck its greasy hands in every multiplayer game known to man.

I did appreciate though that the characters in this game actually seem to know how to use weapons and swing them at a more reasonable speed than Chivalry's who all have their arms trapped in a state of perpetual slow-motion. But there are no commands for vertical or horizontal swings or thrusts so you can't even pretend there is some variety in the combat for a few minutes before realizing all you're supposed to do is run backwards and forwards while swinging.

So ultimately what we have in this game is a more streamlined and dumbed-down Chivalry that kept all of the things that make Chivalry crap. But there's vikings. So it has that going for it.

I'm off to play Blade Of Darkness instead."

reviewText:
Faster paced that WOTR, but also more skill based. The game has been given different dynamics in how to fight like the addition of dodge attacks, sprinting, and high risk, high reward special attacks.

This game has a steep learning curve, but really separates the great players from the average. All the weapons have their strength and weakenesses compared with the other weapons. A really good addition is that classes are given different traits and abilities that make and define them as truly unique. People seem to carry on about poor net coding and lag. To be honest, lag barely occurs any more unless you have high ping (which obviously happens anyway).

Not to mention, the game looks fantastic and the scenery and attention to detail is veryu good. Warriors yell out taunts and battle cries as they clash with the enemy, or yell out warnings if archers are shooting at them. You can customize your warrior to become a beautiful champion of war, and create shields that will cause your hearth and hold to swell with pride!

Wonderful game...Get it!

reviewText:
PROS:
- Sound (music and crispy sound effects of cold weapons and environment.)
- Art direction (skybox, backgrounds, props, etc..)

CONS:
- Sound (voice acting and battle chatter can be cheesy and annoying.)
- Streamlined (AKA dumbed-down) combat system compared to previous installment: War of the Roses.
- Obnoxiously frequent Lag spikes, freezing, and CTD.
- Occasional graphical glitches and other bugs (no blue silhouette around one or a few allies, Doppelgänger of the own player model standing still on random location, etc..)
- Lack of details/underdeveloped or limitations of the game engine (e.g., free fall in water.)
- Broken achievements.
- Toxic community: due to the game being niche, the player base is very small (peak # of players: 100 ~ 140) and generally comprised of either mentally challenged people (e.g., eastern Europe and Americas) or delusional elitists (e.g., the UK.) These hideous players are also very persistent with playing War of the Vikings as if this is the only game they have. Therefore, no high level of decency should be expected.

Final Remarks:
At the time of writing this review, for some strange reason War of the Vikings is incredibly unstable right after official release (beta was smooth) and the developers are incapable of bringing out hotfixes to address game-breaking issues within a month. The game is on a par with the worst game launches in history due to the serious technical issues aforementioned in cons. Paradox and Fatshark did a great job disappointing their fan base once again. If you like wasting your hard-earned money for nothing, or feel sympathy towards incompetent amateurs, this is it.

. RECOMMENDED .

reviewText:
This game is rarely fun. Here are the main reasons why I don't like it:
-There is up 18 seconds respawn time. Like seriously, I don't want to wait that long!
-Ping matters like crazy. Hard to have a good game without a low ping. For some reason, my ping is absurd in this game!
-You can earn gold to buy stuff, but 10+ hours of playing time has earned me like what, 7,000 gold? Thats not even enough to buy ONE cool looking item which is like 8-12k gold.. and which you can only use if you are either Viking or Saxon.. An item is only good for either side.. so lame!!
-There isn't any depth in the game; stats, k/d's, achievements, nothing! The only thing that comes out from a game is gold, which is barley of any use!!
-The server browser (similar to CS), is really dull. The Favorites" server section doesn't even work! I can't add a server into it! It's really just there to look useful.
-You can't browse other servers unless you quit the one you're in. You also can't quit unless you are either alive in the game
date: or you selected the class you chose to respawn in.\n\nTL;DR Game is extremely fustrating!"

reviewText:
UPDATE 03.11.2015/11.03.2015 || Do not buy this game! You have been warned. I wanted to give this game another chance, but there are only a few ppl playing. This game is DEAD. Buy Chivalry instead


Worst game I have ever played. Buggy as hell. Dont buy this game.

- poor performance/optimization on some maps (i7 3770k @4.00Ghz, R9-280X, 8 GB Ram) on monastry and the ice map less than 30 fps.
- every single map favours archers, if the enemy team has +2 archers you lost, because they have unlimited ammo and can spam while you have to fight off enemy melee players.
- 2 handed axes are the best weapon, you can easily hit around the shield even though you block in the swings direction
- spears and enemy players can hit you through a shield when they´re up in your face (cliping through the shield)
- double handed special-attacks don´t 1 shot every time, they clip through the enemy dealing no damage. same with any normal attackPing ~30
- hit registration is buggy as hell. for example, you hit a guy in the head with a javelin, you can see it stuck in his head yet it   deals no damage, or they do 42 dmg even though its a guaranteed 1 hit kill. or enemy does a special attack, he hits the  ground 2m away from me, what happens I die. again im only playing on ~30 ping servers.
- only 4 gamemodes wtf? it gets boring after about 10 hours
- only a few maps, and they´re very similar

+ interesting setting
+ great vareity of weaponry
+ great looking maps level of detail is great, yet they´re quite repetitive
+ player models look great

Conclusion: If you want to play this game every now and then go ahead buy it. if you plan on playing it regulary dont buy it, there are better alternatives like Chivarly. its not worth the money. developer responding in a rude way on constructive bug reporting via email.

reviewText: Before I start this review I'd like to say I've noticed that someone found my review unhelpful so I decided to read through it and noticed I projected more of a mindless rant than anything meaningfully constructive. Though it touts itself as such this game is no longer capable of delivering a skill-based melee combat experience. If you seek a skill-based melee combat experience that's very fun in a duel setting

column26:
The Netcode:

The game made a recent shift in netcode but there are still problems which serve to cripple the element of skill and satisfaction in gameplay. Because of the significant presence of lag between player and server it's not at all uncommon to take damage through your defence
column27: a "parry" put up in the same direction as an incoming attack before it hits
column28: and for attacks that appear to have landed with graphic results to produce no damage at all. Other players may also appear to shift around as the netcode simply can't keep up
column29: interfering with a player's ability to keep track of where their opponent really is as they teleport. The unpredictable nature of server-side lag combined with things happening when it looked like they shouldn't succeeds in delivering a frustrating experience should the player seek for their skilled input to matter.\n\nYou may not understand how important it is for things to be translated from client to server and to the rest of the clients as smoothly and accurately as possible until you see what happens when this isn't the case. If you are not familiar with the defensive mechanic of parrying an enemy attack (in this game and in Warband) then it has to be done before the strike lands (quickly) and in the correct direction to intercept the attack (accurately.) In Warband a successful parry can occur milliseconds before the player takes a hit. Every millisecond in an engagement is important and if the game can't be that accurate then player skill will be marginalized as hits are taken through parries that have been up for up to half a second. 500 milliseconds out of a swing that takes only 600 or 800 to land. Warband
column31:
succeeded in making this work. War of the Vikings failed and it counts significantly against it.

The Player Count:

If you don't live in Europe don't even try. I can scarcely find any North American servers and the game can go plenty of days without ever seeing one. There's a mere 50 players left and almost all of them go to EU servers. For a game that is strictly multiplayer I have no one to play with and that's a very strong reason to pass this one up.

The Mechanics:

I first need to explain the skill demanded by this game. Players must be able to use footwork to narrowly avoid the reach of their enemy's weapons

column34: a skill which is central to the parry/riposte play which much of the community embraces and associates with games like this. Without parry/riposte there's nothing terribly unique about it other than its vikings theme. A class type available to the player
column36: is also a frustrating opponent to deal with. Because the berserker can swing without delay even if his attack has been parried
column37: something that is difficult to do
column38: the player must parry a string of attacks successfully before he may counter-attack. This also serves to further undermine the parry/riposte skill that could have made this game stand out and was indeed why many of its players decided to buy the game. With that gone we no longer have the experience we paid for and if you're looking for the Warband combat experience in a shiny

let me start by saying this is a awesome game.

reviewText:
Fun game when you first get into it. Lacks some depth, squads not really that useful. Game was in EA for months and still riddled with performance and stability bugs. Crashing, random pauses, poor performance at times.

Feels like a good start to a game but does not seem complete yet. I recommend waiting for some of the issues to be addressed.

The game is faster paced than war of the roses which should appeal to a larger audience. A lot of the insta kills are pretty cool to watch. It's similar to WotR but overall a different game and shouldn't be directly compared with it.

Perk system seems rather pointless. Not very many to choose from. A few cool ones...and the rest useless or unappealing. Could also use more classes to customize with.

Shield paint is pretty cool and allows for a unique character to stand out on the battlefield. All weapons and item unlocks are only cosmetic, no strength and weaknesses to different weapons within the same class.

Team death match spawns are pretty close ensuring a lot of action...but many times a little to close resulting in a lot of cheap" kills. Call of Duty style.

Conquest is definately my favorite mode. Though at times a match can degenerate into a TDM feel where people stop going for the objective and just fight around it or chase an enemy all around.

Arena is basically a pitched battle
date:
just in a tiny map. Not a fan at all of this game type. Once you die your out for the round. A team needs to win the best of x amount of rounds to win the match.

Pitched battle is the same game mode only with normal size maps. If you prefer this style of match I highly prefer it to arena.

The game has potential to be more than a TDM killing spree
recommended: but needs a little more goal oriented purpose to matches. An element to encourage a little more stratedgy and keep replayability.\n\nThe combat system over all works pretty smoothly. The hit boxes seem pretty accurate. The sword and shield work well. The 2H axe needs a little work on the annimation and deals damage with the handle of the weapon sometimes. The spear needs animation work as it's completely imposible to visually see a swing in progress. You have the attack direction indicators but there is almost no animation to it. The bows are fun to use
hoursPlayed:
but get very old to be shot with. Might be a little strong at this point as far as how often you can shoot.

Hopefully we get to see the fixes that need to be made and some much needed depth to the game.

6 out of 10."

reviewText:
The blood of a nord runs trough my veins as a true Dane. This game however did my heritage no favors, if you are going to compare this game to chivalry then dont even look at it. The combat contol is unfortunately very poor and though it does succeed in many areas if a game falls short on what its based on then its just a flop for me.

I do not like the following:
-Swing Direction Control
-Blocking Direction Control
-Charge Up Swing
Which is what makes this game frustrating to me. Many of times I attempt to block or attack with a specific direction and if you move your mouse less than an inch in the right direction you could be attacking or blocking with the opposite direction and being that you also move your ENTIRE camera with the mouse it makes manuvering and blocking or attacking at the same time a damned challenge in its self. Charging up your attacks is just useless to me because I rarely use it in a fight and all it ever does is give me something more to pay attention too. Many of times I end up completely missing because of this which in turn gets me killed, fun, but thats just my playstyle ive seen other players use it.

What I do like about this game:
-♥♥♥♥ing vikings man!
-The combat is challenging and the unlock system is very fair
-There are significant punishments for TK'ing and Team Damage
-Working as a team and aiding your allies helps both of you which promotes team playing
-Customization is actually quite diverse (Weapons, Classes, Perks)

Though it has many great traits I wouldnt recommend it to people who get mildly frustrated with a game because this one will do just that. This is based off a ratio of okay games and bad games (Personal). There aren't any good" games here for me and I rarely seem to be making any significant contribution to my team or my score and progress.

TL;DR: Combat Controls suck

reviewText:
Uses the Nine Noble Virtues in a Steam Card even though the NNV are a code of conduct created in the 70's by Norse Pagan reconstructionists. Also, I've seen some Celtic symbols on a few of the Viking items which is silly.

Other than some nitpicks about historical inaccuracies, it is a more refine WotR with less emphasis on armor. No plate archers with spears killing everyone in one shot while not being able to hurt them in return. Instead it is a more arcadey take on their last game and they seem to have realized (some) of their mistakes this time round. Lag still seems to be the deciding factor in most honorable melees and it seems like shields have been broken by this current patch.

Pick it up on sale if you can. That, or wait for an official price drop.

Also, don't even think about buying the Valhalla Edition.

reviewText:
War of the Vikings is a realistic combat simulator, with many similarities to games like Chivalry. This game is exceptionally deep in terms of combat, involving a variety of weapons and angles of attack, and having mechanics that stress immediate reaction to an opponent's movement- instakills are common (which does make learning the game somewhat difficult). This game's atmosphere, though, is what sets it apart from other combat simulation games. Set in old Britain in a war between the Saxons and Vikings, the aesthetic design and overall feel of the game are very genuine. However, a notable vice for this game is in technical issues and latency. Problems can occur such as the game not starting, and in such an action-reaction environment, it can be difficult to fight with 150-300 ping, which is not uncommon. I would recommend this game to people both interested in combat games and old European history, but for those not interested in the historical aspect, there are other games that may be more enjoyable.

Pros:
Well-developed combat system
Exceptional environment/atmosphere

Cons:
Technical issues/latency
Notable learning curve

Overall rating: 70/100
